Description: Lid sherd of Chian black-figured Sphinx and Lion Style pottery stemmed bowl; white slip; glaze fired orange-red; interior reserved; exterior: in upper frieze, lion (only one foreleg remaining) to right; to right possible rump of second lion; incised rosettes as filling ornament; in lower frieze, below pair of lines, part of sphinx (curlicue, wing, rump and tail remaining) to left; at right, trace of undetermined motif; rosette with added red centre as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: Lions are usually depicted seated and facing right, therefore suggesting that the animals on the top frieze are lions. Lemos places this sherd in Group B of the Sphinx and Lion Style. Whilst this may not be a coherent group, the animals depicted on vases of this group all have elongated bodies and the rosette has a daisy shape. For parallels regarding the rosette, see British Museum 1888,0601.473.l.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 147, p. 314, no. 1340)
Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. V, no. 51)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2075) (phase 2)
